definitions.definition: Excessively; too much.
definitions.example: They really went overboard with the party preparations.

overboard.context: Sometimes if I’m not careful, though, I can go a bit overboard.

definitions.definition: To deliberately not listen or pay attention to.
definitions.example: A problem ignored is a problem doubled.

definitions.definition: To pretend to not notice someone or something.
Fail to notice.
Not to know.

ignore.context: I’ve learned that it’s not always possible or even practical to try to perfect your work—sometimes you have to decide what’s important and ignore the rest in order to be productive.

definitions.definition: A person who has knowledge; an informed party.
Having knowledge, especially of a particular subject.
Educated and well informed.

knowledgeable.context: What’s more, I found several of the professors in the department to be exceptionally knowledgeable and stimulating.

definitions.definition: To encourage into action.
To arouse an organism to functional activity.

stimulate.context: What’s more, I found several of the professors in the department to be exceptionally knowledgeable and stimulating.

definitions.definition: Introducing; giving a preview or idea of.
definitions.example: He enrolled in an introductory wine-making course.

introductory.context: Initially I was completely overwhelmed by the introductory chemistry course that I took last year.

definitions.definition: No particular place, noplace.
definitions.example: They went on a cruise to nowhere.

definitions.definition: Unimportant; unworthy of notice.
In no place.
definitions.example: Nowhere did the rules say anything about popcorn.

definitions.definition: To no place.
definitions.example: We sat in traffic, going nowhere.

nowhere.context: No matter how hard I studied, I seemed to be getting nowhere.

definitions.definition: An odd, puzzling or absurd person or thing.
A competition in the answering of questions.
definitions.example: We came second in the pub quiz.

definitions.definition: A school examination of less importance, or of greater brevity, than others given in the same course.
To hoax; to chaff or mock with pretended seriousness of discourse; to make sport of, as by obscure questions.
To peer at; to eye suspiciously or mockingly.
To question closely, to interrogate.
To instruct by means of a quiz.
To play with a quiz.

quiz.context: I failed the first three quizzes.

definitions.definition: Essential or decisive for determining the outcome or future of something; extremely important.
definitions.example: A secure supply of crude oil is crucial for any modern nation, let alone a superpower.

definitions.definition: Cruciform or cruciate; cross-shaped.
(Bermuda) Very good; excellent; particularly applied to reggae music.
definitions.example: Delbert Wilkins is the most crucial pirate radio DJ in Brixton.

crucial.context: More than that, I learned that tackling a new field of study sometimes requires a new approach, not just hard work, and that the help of others can be crucial!

definitions.definition: In an irregular or informal manner; without the usual forms.

informally.context: I have, however, found time to explore the city and make new friends, and I do socialize informally on weekends.

definitions.definition: Impudent beggar
Boisterous, coarse, loose woman
Virago
Random
(aerial freestyle skiing) one and a half twist acrobatic maneuver
Sexually aroused; full of sexual lust.
Rude or coarse in manner.

randy.context: And that’s why I’m so interested in this organization, because, as I understand, Randy Corporation places a great deal of emphasis on R&D, and is also a highly respected leader in the industry.

definitions.definition: Special weight or forcefulness given to something considered important.
definitions.example: He paused for emphasis before saying who had won.

definitions.definition: Special attention or prominence given to something.
definitions.example: Anglia TV's emphasis is on Norwich and district.

definitions.definition: Prominence given to a syllable or words, by raising the voice or printing in italic or underlined type.
definitions.example: He used a yellow highlighter to indicate where to give emphasis in his speech.

definitions.definition: The phonetic or phonological feature that distinguishes emphatic consonants from other consonants.
The use of boldface.

emphasis.context: And that’s why I’m so interested in this organization, because, as I understand, Randy Corporation places a great deal of emphasis on R&D, and is also a highly respected leader in the industry.

definitions.definition: To provoke someone to do wrong, especially by promising a reward; to entice.
definitions.example: She tempted me to eat the apple.

definitions.definition: To attract; to allure.
definitions.example: Its glossy skin tempted me.

definitions.definition: To provoke something; to court.
definitions.example: It would be tempting fate.

tempt.context: It’s true that I’ve been out of my field for the last four years, but I’ve had a number of tempting offers to jump back in.
